post_text: Taylor Fowler, Area Manager (left), and Leslie Breedlove, Director of Operations for the local Cici‚Äôs Pizza franchise (right), presented Charlie Bushyhead, Associate Superintendent of Union Public Schools, with a check for $3,761. On September 3, Cici‚Äôs held a ‚ÄúPizza for PPE‚Äù fundraiser to aid area schools in raising funds to purchase much-needed personal protection equipment. Owner Greg Costley wanted to come up with a way to assist educators in covering these added safety costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Cici‚Äôs generously donated a percentage of proceeds from five Tulsa-area locations and presented a check to Union on Sept. 15. Thank you, Cicis Pizza

post_text:
Gathering Place events will return starting Friday, Sept. 18 with "unique and engaging" events for Tulsa families to safely enjoy for the remainder of 2020, according to a news release.

‚ÄúWe are so pleased to be able to once again resume our programming,‚Äù Tony Moore, executive director, said. ‚ÄúEverything is so different this time around, as we reinvent our approach to programming with respect to social distancing. These family-friendly events can all be experienced with a focus on guest safety; we look forward to sharing this calendar of events as Gathering Place eases back into the event space.‚Äù

The new event calendar includes five free experiences from Sept. 18 through December: https://tulsaworld.com/entertainment/gathering-place-resumes-park-programming/article_2648c0c2-f75c-11ea-b076-dbcecb3ad152.html#tracking-source=home-top-story-1

post_text:
The Tulsa City Council on Wednesday will begin discussing the future of the city‚Äôs mask ordinance and whether to consider lowering the age requirement for wearing one.

The ordinance approved by councilors and signed by the mayor in mid-July set the minimum age at 18. The ordinance expires when Mayor G.T. Bynum‚Äôs civil emergency order expires Nov. 30 or when the ordinance is repealed, modified or extended by the City Council, whichever comes first.

Union Public Schools requires everyone and all ages to wear masks while at school.

See story: https://tulsaworld.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/tulsa-councilors-to-mull-lowering-age-requirement-for-masks/article_4557952a-f69d-11ea-b570-03b471caadbb.html#tracking-source=home-the-latest

September 15 to October 15 is National Hispanic American Heritage Month. During #HispanicHeritageMonth, take some time to educate yourself and your kids on the vast and diverse Hispanic history. https://hispanicheritagemonth.gov

Be sure to like our new Spanish Facebook too: https://www.facebook.com/EscuelasPublicasdeUnion

National Hispanic Heritage Month traditionally honors the cultures and contributions of both Hispanic and Latino Americans as we celebrate heritage rooted in all Latin American countries.

post_text:
IN THE NEWS: Both schoolteachers, Matt McAfee and his wife, Kelsey, share more than a passion for education.

They also want to change literary culture for area youth.

‚ÄúThere are a lot of kids who have already decided that don‚Äôt like to read,‚Äù said Kelsey, an English instructor at Union Eighth Grade Center. ‚ÄúA lot of that comes from the way that reading has been framed and by the way that they‚Äôve grown up. Even by age 14, they think reading is work. They think that reading is only books about X,Y and Z.

‚Äú... It‚Äôs not like that anymore. There‚Äôs a book for everybody. I always tell my kids, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs not that you don‚Äôt like reading. You just don‚Äôt like the books you‚Äôve read so far.‚Äô‚Äù

The McAfees plan to increase such opportunities.

Their store, Eleanor‚Äôs Bookshop, is among five outlets at the Shops at Mother Road Market.

Continue: https://tulsaworld.com/business/shops-at-mother-road-market-prepares-for-opening-this-weekend/article_8640a398-f214-11ea-965b-0b994bed2aec.html?fbclid=IwAR0de5VQGHRIHvrwcE46_1Y-JsjOaHcHYZcgLaaV4wf7ESQ-WlrkisEn-q0

post_text:
Union Public Schools has shut down 12 classrooms after an increase in COVID-19 cases within the district.
Nearly three weeks into the school year, Union Public Schools said there are 345 people across the district either isolated or quarantined because of positive COVID-19 cases.

Out of about 9,600 students who are learning in person, the district said 21 have tested positive for COVID-19. Eleven staff members also have the virus.

The spike in cases is prompting classrooms to shut down at Jarman, Darnaby, McAuliffe and Moore elementary schools, along with one class at the high school.

https://www.newson6.com/story/5f5a8595a45193732009b430/union-public-schools-closes-12-classrooms-amid-uptick-in-covid19-cases

post_text: All 12 National Merit Semifinalists honored today at Union High School.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA
September 9 at 3:19 PM ¬∑

All 12 National Merit Semifinalists were feted in a recognition ceremony this afternoon at the Grand Hall at Union High School.
Observing COVID-19 protocols, the High School invited parents and administrators, including Superintendent Dr. Kirt Hartzler, to recognize and congratulate the students. There were also light refreshments for students.
Dr. Hartzler commended the students for having one of the largest groups of seniors to be recognized as National Merit Semifinalists, saying he considers the honor to be among the school district‚Äôs highest academic achievements.
Senior Class Principal Marla Robinson also congratulated and spoke highly of the seniors, and after seniors finished refreshments, she spoke with them and their parents on the next steps in order to be considered National Merit Finalists, which are announced in February.
‚ÄúWe have high expectations for all of you,‚Äù Hartzler said. ‚ÄúYou have set the bar high.‚Äù
text:
All 12 National Merit Semifinalists honored today at Union High School.

September 9 at 3:19 PM ¬∑

All 12 National Merit Semifinalists were feted in a recognition ceremony this afternoon at the Grand Hall at Union High School.
Observing COVID-19 protocols, the High School invited parents and administrators, including Superintendent Dr. Kirt Hartzler, to recognize and congratulate the students. There were also light refreshments for students.
Dr. Hartzler commended the students for having one of the largest groups of seniors to be recognized as National Merit Semifinalists, saying he considers the honor to be among the school district‚Äôs highest academic achievements.
Senior Class Principal Marla Robinson also congratulated and spoke highly of the seniors, and after seniors finished refreshments, she spoke with them and their parents on the next steps in order to be considered National Merit Finalists, which are announced in February.
‚ÄúWe have high expectations for all of you,‚Äù Hartzler said. ‚ÄúYou have set the bar high.‚Äù

The purpose of intramural sports is to promote participation and develop basic skills.

post_text:
Getting lunch at Union Public Schools may be a little different but it is just as tasty.

These Andersen second graders mask up, pick up their meals in the cafeteria and return to the classroom to eat at their classrooms. Students in grades 2-5 pick up their meals to take their classrooms while adults deliver meals to the younger classes.

Meanwhile at the Union 8th Grade Center, lunch is split into four cohorts so there are only about 200 students at in the commons area at any one time. Each table has Plexiglas partitions to provide a barrier between students as they eat. Ropes between the cafeteria and the walkways also help students and staff to social distance. When students leave the cafeteria, crews clean the tables and Plexiglas partitions before the next cohort arrives.

Lisa Griffin, director of Child Nutrition, said her staff works diligently not only to provide good, nutritious meals but to ensure that staff is safe as well. And, thanks to the USDA, all meals ‚Äì breakfast and lunch ‚Äì are free through December 31. See related story: https://bit.ly/3i2ELKL

post_text:
Government Finance Officers Association of the United States and Canada (GFOA) has awarded the Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting to Union Public Schools, Independent District No. 9 for its comprehensive annual financial report (CAFR) for the fiscal year ended June 30, 2019. The CAFR has been judged by an impartial panel to meet the high standards of the program, which includes demonstrating a constructive "spirit of full disclosure" to clearly communicate its financial story and motivate potential users and user groups to read the CAFR.

The Certificate of Achievement is the highest form of recognition in the area of governmental accounting and financial reporting, and its attainment represents a significant accomplishment by a government and its management.

Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA) advances excellence in government finance by providing best practices, professional development, resources, and practical research for more than 21,000 members and the communities they serve.

post_text: Union freshman return to learn.
shared_text:
UHS Freshman Academy added 106 new photos to the album: First Week at School.
August 25 at 2:58 PM ¬∑

Students and teachers have returned to learning in person at the Union High School Freshman Academy.

A number of students are also taking freshman classes virtually. In some of the pictures in this album, you might notice how teachers have combined a biology class in which students - both in-person and virtually - are being taught in the same cohort.

The school has made many efforts to keep students safe, from mandating masks to continually cleaning surfaces. In the commons area where freshman eat, plastic shields have been been put in place on the tables to help protect students while they eat unmasked.

In another scene, you will notice that wearing masks, did not stop students from engaging in physical activities like learning how to use a pogo stick. Keep practicing!

--

Visit https://www.unionps.org/coronavirus for complete details on the return-to-school plans for students, parents and teachers in English & Spanish, as well as frequently asked questions.

--English Version: https://bit.ly/3fpgRrB

--Spanish Version: https://bit.ly/2Ok1uVp

See FAQ: https://bit.ly/2ZV8Kh2

post_text: 3-year-old students head to class!
shared_text:
Rosa Parks Early Childhood Education Center
August 24 at 3:28 PM ¬∑

Temperatures taken. Check. Masks worn. Check. Name tags. Check. Cute kids. Check.

It was a busy morning this as a team of staff and teachers, lead by Principal Alycia Pennington welcomed 3-year-old students to school, conducting temperature checks and making sure young kids were wearing masks.

If there were any tears, they were mostly seen on parents who watched from their vehicles as Union staff escorted their children inside.

post_text:
Attention Union Students in Grade 6-12: Your Union student EMAIL has changed.

PLEASE FOLLOW THE DIRECTIONS BELOW TO ACCESS YOUR EMAIL.

‚Ä¢ YOUR NEW USERNAME IS ‚Äús‚Äù plus your student ID number plus ‚Äú@unionps.org‚Äù.
o Example: if your student ID number is 010101 then your new user name is s010101@unionps.org
‚Ä¢ YOUR NEW PASSWORD IS ‚ÄúUn‚Äù plus your six digit birthday.
o Example: if your birthday is 08/05/2002 then your new password is Un080502.
o You have the ability to change your password after you log in with the initial new username and password. Changing is recommended.
YOUR UNION STUDENT EMAIL HAS CHANGED. You must follow these directions to access your Union email.
Thank you.
And thanks for making sure your friends and classmates in your cohort have completed this also! We will rise together!

‚Ä¢ YOUR NEW USERNAME IS ‚Äús‚Äù plus your student ID number plus ‚Äú@unionps.org‚Äù.
o Example: if your student ID number is 010101 then your new user name is s010101@unionps.org
‚Ä¢ YOUR NEW PASSWORD IS ‚ÄúUn‚Äù plus your six digit birthday.
o Example: if your birthday is 08/05/2002 then your new password is Un080502.
o You have the ability to change your password after you log in with the initial new username and password. Changing is recommended.
YOUR UNION STUDENT EMAIL HAS CHANGED. You must follow these directions to access your Union email.
Thank you.
And thanks for making sure your friends and classmates in your cohort have completed this also! We will rise together!

post_text:
Curbside Virtual Student Device Pick Up for all Union School Sites - Elementary & Secondary - will be SATURDAY, August 22, from 10 a.m.until 4 p.m. at each school site. Please remain in your vehicles. Staff will deliver any devices as well as back-to-school packets. Again, this event is for families who have enrolled for virtual learning for the first semester at Union Public Schools.

If you are a secondary student and did not get your device during schedule pickup, you may visit your school site Saturday to pick up your device.

Union Public Schools, T-Mobile and Tulsa Responds have joined forces to ensure that every Union family who can demonstrate a need will have a wireless Hotspot and in home access to internet at ZERO cost to you.
The hotspots will temporarily keep your kids connected at home while we work to install internet service at your residence for the entire school year. Qualifying families will be contacted by a Tulsa Responds navigator in the coming weeks who will guide you through every step of installation.

CONTACT US: internet@tulsaresponds.org

Union Public Schools has received its portion of the state‚Äôs $10 million in PPE (personal protective equipment) from the Tulsa Area Emergency Management Agency.

The supplies include:

Children masks ‚Äì 22430
Adult masks ‚Äì 13550
Gloves, small ‚Äì 4000
Gloves, medium ‚Äì 14400
Gloves, Lrg. ‚Äì 17300
Gloves, X-larg ‚Äì 21300
Face shields ‚Äì 1025
Gowns ‚Äì 28740

The supplies are being stored in the Union warehouse while officials plan distribution of the PPE to the sites, according to David Young, dierector of Purchasing and Supply Management.

Related story: https://www.newson6.com/story/5f3d17538382de105430e8ee/10-million-in-ppe-to-be-distributed-to-oklahoma-schools-soon

post_text:
Union Public Schools officials explain how distance learning will be used in secondary schools (Grades 6-12) in 2020-2021. In the event there is an interruption of in-person learning, Union will fall back on distance learning. We have made significant changes to distance learning, including expectation of new learning that meets Oklahoma Academic Standards, taking daily attendance, daily work/expectations, and more.

View Elementary Distance Learning Plan Here: https://youtu.be/ikN6_l8VKcs

View Union's Return to School Plan: https://www.unionps.org/coronavirus

August 17, 2020 #UnionSchools #DistanceLearning #Secondary

UHS Freshman Academy
August 17 at 12:59 PM ¬∑

Since our #UFA students were unable to tour the school, our amazing Student Leadership team made color-coded signs for our hallways! The hallways are grouped by subject, and now each hallway has corresponding color signs that will help them find their way.

We'll also have staff & teachers in the hallways to help during each transition period - Don't worry - we'll get through this together!

Watch our social media for more information & tips as we get closer to our first day back to school.

post_text: Thank you, Christian Chapel for making Jarman Elementary School shine just a little brighter.
shared_text:
Jarman Elementary - Union Public Schools
August 15 at 12:46 PM ¬∑

Jarman is blessed to have several amazing Community Partners who do so much to support our teachers and school. Today, members of Christian Chapel spent the day trimming trees, digging up stumps, and planting new beautiful flowers and bushes to give Jarman a special look at we prepare to head back to schools. Here are a few pictures of the day. Check back later for pictures of the finished project!

post_text:
The city of Tulsa announced Thursday that it will pour $5.6 million in federal funds into high-speed internet services to help low-income families bridge the digital divide as the pandemic drives students to distance learning.

Gov. Kevin Stitt on Thursday awarded the city nearly $31 million in CARES Act funds that Mayor G.T. Bynum said will help cover unbudgeted costs incurred because of the pandemic.

The mayor said the nearly $31 million allocation will help in several key areas, of which he specifically highlighted the city‚Äôs Internet Access Plan.

See story: https://tulsaworld.com/news/local/tulsa-will-spend-5-6-million-in-cares-act-funds-connecting-families-to-internet-to/article_874b6328-2200-5d47-9942-b74aea5d9060.html

post_text:
Interim Health Commissioner Lance Frye on Thursday issued a new statewide health advisory calling on all Oklahomans to strengthen their commitment to combating COVID-19 in the state.

The Safer in Oklahoma Health Advisory reinforces public health precautions and includes recommendations including increased public and private testing capacity and more tests with a turnaround time of 48 hours or less.

The advisory also recommends an enhanced data collection system; mask recommendations for people 11 and older, for populations in communal living facilities; mask and table distancing guidelines for restaurants when the county is in elevated (red or orange) alert levels; a mask policy for travelers entering Oklahoma from areas with high levels of community spread; a limit to indoor gatherings; and recommended weekly testing for all staff members at long-term care facilities.

See story: https://journalrecord.com/2020/08/13/frye-issues-safer-in-oklahoma-health-advisory-new-recommendations/

post_text:
Weathermen are not the only professionals who use green screens.

Green screens come in handy for Union District Teacher Trainers, who don't want to cut off part of their heads in training, using Zoom, for some 110 teachers during New Teacher Induction this week. Sharing the same classroom space at the Service Center, the trainers lead discussions for NTI which ends this Friday.

All teachers will report to work Monday.

Pictured are Andrea Gaines, Dr. Shannan Bittle, Susan Hickey, and Julie Gardner.

District teacher trainers coordinate specific areas of the curriculum as noted below:

English Language Arts
English Learners
Math
Science
Social Studies
STEM

Chasity Gray, Director of Professional Learning, oversees NTI and Professional Learning, works with Lisa Witcher, Senior Executive Director of Instructional Services, who oversee the training.

Learn more:

https://www.unionps.org/professionallearning

https://www.unionps.org/InstructionalServices

post_text:
Message to Union Staff

Union Family,

As we prepare for Back to School, this is usually the time that we are finalizing our Kickoff show to celebrate the people, accomplishments, and events that make us uniquely Union. This year, however, we will not have a kickoff extravaganza in the Performing Arts Center. Therefore, on Monday, August 17, all teaching staff and site-based support personnel will report directly to their school site at 8:00 a.m., unless you‚Äôve been told to do something else. All Support Services and ESC employees will report to their work assignments as usual or as directed by their manager.

Although this isn‚Äôt the usual start to the school year, our focus is still the same‚Äîprovide meaningful educational opportunities for every student entrusted to us. And our mission continues to be to graduate 100% of our students college and career ready.

I look forward to working beside you in the days ahead knowing that, ‚ÄúTogether We Make a Difference.‚Äù

Sincerely,

Kirt Hartzler, Ed.D.
Superintendent
Union Public Schools

post_text:
Tulsa family wins national praise just for being nice

Says Retired Jarman Principal Patti Pitcock, "I taught this young man and his brother at Darnaby. Great family."

---

A neighbor and his two teenage sons came to mow Karen Simonson‚Äôs grass last spring during the most restrictive phase of Tulsa‚Äôs COVID-19 shutdown.

‚ÄúLet us pay you,‚Äù she offered.

‚ÄúNo, no, no,‚Äù the neighbor said. Schools were closed. His work had gone online. And they were looking for ways to stay busy, he told her. They even put a notice online offering to mow other yards in the neighborhood for free.

Bong Kang and his family, however, had made a habit of being nice to their neighbors long before the coronavirus.

Read Tulsa World story: https://tulsaworld.com/news/tulsa-family-wins-national-praise-just-for-being-nice/article_13d1236b-3d3e-5a7f-b0b1-69b98e31a3bf.html

post_text: What will Union Choirs look like this year?
shared_text:
Union Choirs - Tulsa, OK
August 13 at 11:25 AM ¬∑

What will Union Choirs look like this year?

Every teacher has adjusted rehearsal spaces to accommodate proper social distancing to the best of their ability. Many of the high school choirs will be holding rehearsals in the PAC or band rooms. As soon as numbers are set for the year, we are planning to purchase singing specific masks for each student. We will be limiting the duration we sing and spreading it out throughout the hour, per the aerosol specific study guidelines. We will be doing our absolute best to follow all CDC regulations, while continuing to hold classes and foster a sense of community.

Please contact your child‚Äôs teacher for any further questions.

6th- Linda Davis
Davis.linda@unionps.org

7th- Lindsay Smith
Smith.lindsaya@unionps.org

8th- Tyler Acord
Acord.tyler@unionps.org

9th & HS- Scott Zenthoefer & Daniel Frerichs
Zenthoefer.scott@unionps.org
Frerichs.daniel@unionps.org

post_text:
COVID-19 KID CARE RESOURCE PORTAL
This citywide online portal will provide access to critical resources in response to the COVID-19 crisis, including childcare, meals, and educational activities. Through this portal, businesses and community groups will be able to share details of support they can offer, such as care sites, food, or other resources. Families and children impacted by COVID-19 will be able to use this portal to easily locate and get connected to these vital resources.

Details: http://covidkidcareresources.tauw.org/?fbclid=IwAR2FDSIqgO_knsKrrlwtja-9L88Vfp5k_OdqxVy_V5Yh-S7gr8V0CLcv3QY

Congratulations are in order for Joshua Robinson. He is not just director of Operations for Union Public Schools. Now, he is also a doctor. Robinson graduated from The University of Oklahoma May 8, 2020, and earned his doctorate degree in Educational Administration Curriculum, and Supervision Ed.D. His staff celebrated with him yesterday.
Congratulations, Dr. Joshua Robinson.

Ellen Ochoa, Jefferson and the 6th/7th Grade will continue to offer free meals for all children through Thursday, August 20. Union virtual student meals will be available for pick up at your student‚Äôs school starting August 24, and will be offered according to your student‚Äôs meal status-free, reduced or paid. More information about these meals and an order form will be sent out at a later date. Any questions? Call 918-357-6131.

The hours through August 20 will be 9:30 a.m. ‚Äì 11:30 a.m. Mondays through Thursdays. Double meals will be served on Thursdays (for Friday.) Pick-up will be at:

Ellen Ochoa Elementary, 12000 E. 31st Street
6th/7th Grade Center, 10100 E. 61st Street
Jefferson Elementary, 8418 S. 107th E. Ave.

Two meals, breakfast and lunch, will be available for FREE drive-through pick up for any children through the summer until further notice. Children do not have to be currently enrolled at Union Public Schools for the summer meals.

Cherokee Nation and Cherokee Nation Health Services have created a voucher program to help more Cherokee citizens purchase new eyeglasses regardless of their age, income or health diagnosis.

The Eyeglass Program is designed to help Cherokees who have been examined by a Cherokee Nation Health Services optometry provider to purchase new eyewear with a $200 voucher beginning August 17.

Details: https://www.anadisgoi.com/index.php/government-stories/380-cherokee-nation-offers-eyeglass-program-to-all-cherokee-nation-citizens-beginning-august-17

post_text:
Union Superintendent Dr. Kirt Hartzler welcomed new teachers to Union Public Schools and wished them ‚Äúan amazing year,‚Äù during these uncertain times as Oklahoma faces the COVID-19 pandemic. There may be a storm but like all storms ‚Äì even long ones ‚Äì ‚Äúthis storm will also come to an end,‚Äù Hartzler said. ‚ÄúWe got this. ‚Ä¶ Keep your heads up.‚Äù

There are 110 staff members participating in New Teacher Induction this year through a series of Zoom sessions, offered by Teaching and Learning and Human Resources, which are designed to introduce and welcome new teachers to Union Public Schools and how it conducts school business.

Chasity Gray, director of Professional Learning, who oversees the induction, is leading many of the Zooms and has invited several administrators and guest speakers to speak throughout this week.

‚ÄúThis is my 35th year in education,‚Äù Hartzler told teachers, noting however, this is the first time he has had to address teachers via Zoom. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs OK. We can adapt.‚Äù

Continue reading: https://www.unionps.org/272623_2?articleID=58193

Union Public Schools Superintendent Kirt Hartzler will recommend starting the upcoming year through distance learning Monday evening.

The school board will vote on the superintendent‚Äôs recommendation during its Monday meeting. If the proposal is approved, Union will become the latest district in the Tulsa metro to forgo its plans for in-person instruction due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

Board members at Union originally approved a plan in which the district would offer in-person and online ‚Äúpathways‚Äù for students to return to classes this month. Students and employees would have been required to wear masks while at school.

For those of you who would like to watch the meeting from the convenience of your own home, you may view the livestream link here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CP2oUfmVtDY

See: https://tulsaworld.com/news/local/education/union-public-schools-board-to-vote-on-distance-learning-proposal-monday/article_4a64d293-e201-5461-a187-ffa2aefce202.html

Join Tulsa City/County Library for a Zoom webinar for an introduction to using Canva, an online design tool. Canva is a great tool to create graphics of a variety of sizes useful for many social media sites!

Want to create posters and other graphics for your business or personal projects, but don‚Äôt know where to start? Join us as we explore Canva, a free graphic design tool.

This talk will be of interest to you whether you are a technology expert or enthusiast, or just want to learn more about how technology works.

Registrants will need to provide an email address. The Zoom login information will be emailed out an hour prior to the program. A recording of the talk will be uploaded to YouTube.

https://events.tulsalibrary.org/event/4464845

post_text:
As school districts across the state prepare to welcome students back to class in a matter of weeks, the Oklahoma State Department of Education has updated its guidelines to help schools navigate challenges in the midst of the pandemic.

On Wednesday, the department updated the ‚ÄòReturn to Learn Oklahoma‚Äô plan.

‚ÄúPlanning for and starting the 2020-21 school year will be far different than the start of any school
year in the past. The upcoming school year is likely to include short-term disruptions to instruction
in response to COVID-19. As a result, it is imperative that schools now consider adjustments and
plan contingencies for day-to-day operations so that any short-term (or longer) disruptions are
minimized while ensuring adherence to public health guidance,‚Äù the document reads.

Continue: https://kfor.com/news/covid-19-school-plan/education-officials-update-oklahomas-return-to-learn-plan-to-address-contact-tracing-emergency-drills/

post_text:
When COVID-19 first came to Tulsa County in March, many local school districts were preparing for spring break. They had to quickly pivot and change to distance and virtual learning using a variety of methods.

Since then, COVID-19 has continued to affect residents of Tulsa, and school districts have had to make contingency plans for the upcoming school year.

At Union Public Schools, the district is weighing two options: face-to-face learning and virtual learning. A lot of effort is focusing on distance learning, says Sandi Calvin, assistant superintendent.

The district has a re-entry task force, which meets weekly to prepare for the upcoming school year. Each student will get a device ‚Äî iPads for younger students and laptops for older students ‚Äî and WiFi access, if needed.

Continue reading Tulsa People article: https://www.tulsapeople.com/city-desk/the-test/article_fa9c9ff6-d1d7-11ea-950d-8be705850945.html

post_text:
Nurses, mechanics, maintenance teams and many other support positions that keep districts functioning wonder who is looking out for them as back to school plans are finalized and distance-learning looms with potential job insecurity.

TPS has about 2,500 support personnel. That is about the same amount for Union Public Schools.

‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs what gets lost in all this. We‚Äôve got over 2,000 staff members that we have to be highly concerned about,‚Äù said Dr. Kirt Hartzler, UPS Superintendent.

In the reopening schools framework by the Oklahoma State Department of Education is an adaptive staffing plan for districts. It says districts have broad authority over employee work schedules and are encouraged to accommodate staff members to the extent possible.

Continue: https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/back-to-school-plans-have-school-support-personnel-worried-for-safety-and-job-security

post_text: Wondering how you can do your daily activities safely while protecting yourself and your loved ones from COVID-19?
shared_text:
Tulsa Health Department
July 29 at 9:49 AM ¬∑

Wondering how you can do your daily activities safely while protecting yourself and your loved ones from COVID-19? The more closely you interact with others and the longer that interaction, the higher the risk of COVID-19 spread.

So, think about:
How many people will be there?
Will the space be indoors or outdoors?
Will you spend a lot of time with others?
(‚ÄúPST‚Äù here‚Äôs a hint ‚Äì think People, Space and Time.)

Learn more about assessing the risk when you‚Äòre deciding to go out: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/deciding-to-go-out.html

UYFA Spirit
July 27 at 11:40 AM ¬∑

Camp is Aug 3, 4, & 5 - Please see the attached flyer for what to wear and times.
MASK are REQUIRED!!!!!

Drop off -
Will be curbside, please be ready to answer a few questions about possible Covid exposure. I just don't feel some of our littles would be able to answer those questions completely. We will be taking temperatures everyday and stressing the importance of washing their hands. NO parents will be allowed inside the building unless they are a parent sponsor.

During camp -
We are waiting for an answer back from Union if we can put tape on the floor to space the girls out. Even if they come back and say no, we will still be able to spread out effectively because our numbers are down, 3 different spaces to utilize and with different groups that will help as well.

Parent Showing -
We are looking at the parent showing being outside because well the ever present Covid! I'm purchasing a sound machine to make this possible because I feel it's important. So please plan on bringing a folding chair to space out and get to see what your daughter has learned during camp.

post_text:
Looking forward to graduating this spring from Union High School, Lucy Villasis Cano expected to go straight to a four-year university. But of course, she didn‚Äôt plan on COVID-19.

The epidemic, while not the only factor influencing Villasis Cano‚Äôs decision, helped convince her to stay closer to home for now.

‚ÄúWith everything that‚Äôs going on,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúmy parents won‚Äôt have to stress out anymore and they‚Äôll have two more years to save up for when I transfer.‚Äù

Instead of going straight to the University of Oklahoma to study law, Villasis Cano will take advantage of free tuition at Tulsa Community College, where she can earn an associate degree before moving to Norman in 2022.

Continue: https://tulsaworld.com/news/despite-covid-19-fewer-students-are-taking-advantage-of-free-tuition-at-tcc/article_08988612-fe92-554d-a4ac-24ad29042808.html

post_text:
The clock is ticking and the pressure is on for area school districts and the start of school.

‚ÄúA lot of families are really pleading for more information,‚Äù said Oklahoma Superintendent of Public Instruction, Joy Hofmeister.

‚ÄúThere are so many moving parts to this and just so many unknowns,‚Äù said Dr. Kirt Hartzler, Union Public Schools Superintendent.

‚ÄúThe plan, right now, is for us to attempt to have in person learning on August 24,‚Äù Dr. Hartzler said.

UPS has an online option too and masks are required for every Union student and staff member on campus.

Dr. Hartzler said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking large schools. Even if you were to go with a hybrid schedule, dividing students up at 50%, you still have to worry about congregating and still trying to physically distance kids. It‚Äôs tough to do.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/green-countrys-three-largest-districts-state-navigate-back-to-school-plans-a-lot-of-families-are-really-pleading-for-more-information
shared_text:
KJRH.COM
Green Country's three largest districts, state navigate back-to-school plans: 'A lot of families are really pleading for more information'
text:
The clock is ticking and the pressure is on for area school districts and the start of school.

‚ÄúA lot of families are really pleading for more information,‚Äù said Oklahoma Superintendent of Public Instruction, Joy Hofmeister.

‚ÄúThere are so many moving parts to this and just so many unknowns,‚Äù said Dr. Kirt Hartzler, Union Public Schools Superintendent.

‚ÄúThe plan, right now, is for us to attempt to have in person learning on August 24,‚Äù Dr. Hartzler said.

UPS has an online option too and masks are required for every Union student and staff member on campus.

Dr. Hartzler said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre talking large schools. Even if you were to go with a hybrid schedule, dividing students up at 50%, you still have to worry about congregating and still trying to physically distance kids. It‚Äôs tough to do.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/green-countrys-three-largest-districts-state-navigate-back-to-school-plans-a-lot-of-families-are-really-pleading-for-more-information

The July Series on Race and Equity will end with two sessions you don‚Äôt want to miss!

Lindsey Cain and Linda Felstein will facilitate a discussion on author Ijeoma Oluo‚Äôs seminal book on race and racism, So You Want to Talk About Race, on Thursday, July 30.

On Friday, July 31, the final session Putting the Pieces Together, is a cumulative review of all the racial equity topics discussed during the series, with a focus to transform learned content into actionable steps to develop a more anti-biased/anti-racist culture at Union.

post_text:
Football, other high school sports seasons remain on schedule, but situation is `so fluid'

Football and other fall high school sports will continue to proceed as scheduled in Oklahoma.

That message was emphasized Thursday by Oklahoma Secondary School Activities Association executive director David Jackson during a Zoom meeting update with media.

Jackson, however, did note that circumstances involving COVID-19 could dictate a move into another direction.

Jackson said moving some or all fall sports to the spring semester has been considered as the OSSAA looks to proceed in as ‚Äúsafe a manner as we possibly can.‚Äù

See story: https://tulsaworld.com/news/football-other-high-school-sports-seasons-remain-on-schedule-but-situation-is-so-fluid/article_97aa9026-2dab-517c-878c-47729c720ad1.html

Still time to get free tuition at Tulsa Community College
Graduating high school seniors can see how to apply here.

Fox 23 featured a story on the process with Union graduate Lucy Villasis Cano. Classes start August 17.

Students have just a little while longer to sign up for the Tulsa Achieves program meant for 2020 graduating seniors in Tulsa County with a 2.0 or higher GPA.

Participating students have to commit to attending TCC for the fall semester after their high school graduation.

post_text: It might not have been the graduation they planned, but the Class of 2020 still saw fireworks during their seniors-only graduation ceremony at Union Tuttle Stadium Thursday evening, July 23.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA added 263 new photos to the album: 2020 Seniors Only Graduation ‚Äî at UnionHigh School.
July 24 at 9:08 AM ¬∑ Tulsa, OK ¬∑

It might not have been the graduation they planned, but the Class of 2020 still saw fireworks during their seniors-only graduation ceremony at Union Tuttle Stadium Thursday evening, July 23.

About 700 seniors in caps and gowns - and a variety of masks because of Covid-19 - participated in the seniors-only graduation program at Union Tuttle Stadium Thursday, July 23.

Each senior received a special mask, and a bottle of water as well to help cope with the hot weather. (Seniors were allowed to remove masks during their walk for picture-taking purposes.)

The ceremony started with celebratory videos, followed by a short introduction and recognition of seniors ‚Äì from distinguished graduates to seniors of the month. Then, seniors ‚Äì following social distancing protocols ‚Äì walked across the stage to cheers as they heard their names called out for their friends and small number of family members just outside the stadium.

The graduation concluded with a singing of the alma mater and surprise fireworks from the top of the UMAC.

See video of the event here: https://youtu.be/bpu6Yp7xB6M

post_text: Union High School is set up and ready for tonight's Seniors-Only Graduation at 8 p.m.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA
July 23 at 7:32 AM ¬∑

Union High School is set up and ready for tonight's Seniors-Only Graduation at 8 p.m.

The ceremony will be streamed here: https://www.youtube.com/c/unionuview.

Seniors: It will be warm! Please hydrate prior to coming to the graduation. We will have a bottle of water for you at the ceremony, but please drink multiple bottles of water throughout the day to get a head start on hydration.

Please park in the north parking lot by the College and Career Center. Gates will open at 7:15 pm. Please be in your seat by 7:45 pm so we are able to start the ceremony on time.

Finally- in compliance with the City of Tulsa mask ordinance, you will be required to wear a mask during the ceremony. We will provide a mask for you. Masks may be taken down when you are walking across the stage to get your picture taken.

More details here: https://www.unionps.org/Commencement

post_text: High School yearbooks have arrived.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA
July 22 at 3:40 PM ¬∑

2019-2020 Yearbooks Are Here

Curbside Pick-up Times
Wednesday, July 29, 9 a.m -1 p.m.
Thursday, July 30, from 2 p.m. - 6 p.m.

Please stay in your car and pull up to the doors on the north side of the High School. We will meet you there.

If you are picking up your prepaid yearbook, please bring your school I.D.
If you are purchasing a yearbook, you may pay with cash, card, money order, or check. Each yearbook is $80.
*If you cannot pick up your yearbook on one of the scheduled dates, you can pick up your yearbook once the building is open for student entry.

Please email hsyearbook@unionps.org if you have any questions.

post_text:
Class of 2020 Seniors: We are excited to see you and celebrate you tomorrow! We wanted to offer a few reminders about tomorrow night.

It will be warm! Please hydrate prior to coming to the graduation. We will have a bottle of water for you at the ceremony, but please drink multiple bottles of water throughout the day to get a head start on hydration.

Please park in the north parking lot by the College and Career Center. Gates will open at 7:15 pm. Please be in your seat by 7:45 pm so we are able to start the ceremony on time.

Finally- in compliance with the City of Tulsa mask ordinance, you will be required to wear a mask during the ceremony. We will provide a mask for you. Masks may be taken down when you are walking across the stage to get your picture taken.

We are looking forward to seeing you tomorrow night at 7:15.

Principal John Chargois

July 20 at 4:10 PM ¬∑

7th Grade Drive Thru Schedule & Laptop Pick Up. To reduce wait time, please come at your scheduled time. All 7th Graders must have proof of TDAP immunization or waiver in order to receive a schedule. If you are unable to come at your scheduled time, please come at the last slot of the day.

7th Grade Pick Up by Last Names

Monday, August 10
A-E: 8-9 AM
F-K: 9-10 AM
L-P: 10-11 AM
Q-T: 11-12 PM
U-Z: 12-1 PM

Tuesday, August 11
A-E: 2-3 PM
F-K: 3-4 PM
L-P: 4-5 PM
Q-T: 5-6 Pm
U-Z: 6-7 PM

Pickup will be done curbside as you remain in your vehicles - parent/student will be given a packet including:

Student ID
Class Schedule
School map
Parent Portal Instructions
Parent Canvas Account Instructions

And IT will issue to your student:

Laptop
Case

Union Public Schools will continue to offer FREE drive-thru meal pick-ups at three Union sites through August 13.

The hours will be 9:30 a.m. ‚Äì 11:30 a.m. Mondays through Thursdays. Double meals will be served on Thursdays (for Friday.) Pick-up will be at:

Ellen Ochoa Elementary, 12000 E. 31st Street
6th/7th Grade Center, 10100 E. 61st Street
Jefferson Elementary, 8418 S. 107th E. Ave. Jeffer

Meals, which include breakfast and lunch, ‚Äì will be available for FREE drive-through pick up for any children through the summer until August 13. Children do not have to be currently enrolled at Union Public Schools.

July 14 at 1:45 PM ¬∑

JULY SERIES ON RACE & EQUITY
Lindsey Cain and Linda Felstein from the Union Reach Team will continue to facilitate sessions with guest speakers on the topics of race and equity for the remaining Fridays in July. Join us as for a collaboration toward a more equitable Union experience as we prepare for the academic year. All meetings will be held on Zoom from 2:00 ‚Äì 3:30 p.m.

Zoom Meeting Info here: https://www.unionps.org/272622_2?articleID=56771
text:
Lindsey Cain and Linda Felstein will conduct the second of a series of sessions on race and equity for the month of July. Reducing Racial Bias in the Classroom will take place on Friday, July 24, 2020 at 2:00 pm. It will be facilitated by Avery Marshall, Director of Programs, at the Oklahoma Center for Community and Justice (OCCJ). Mr. Marshall‚Äôs work is focused on social justice, equity and inclusion. He heads the Anytown Leadership Institute for incoming high school sophomores, juniors, and seniors, which develops awareness and skills for individuals to lead in a diverse community.

See post below for Zoom Info.

Union Public Schools - Tulsa, OK
July 14 at 1:45 PM ¬∑

JULY SERIES ON RACE & EQUITY
Lindsey Cain and Linda Felstein from the Union Reach Team will continue to facilitate sessions with guest speakers on the topics of race and equity for the remaining Fridays in July. Join us as for a collaboration toward a more equitable Union experience as we prepare for the academic year. All meetings will be held on Zoom from 2:00 ‚Äì 3:30 p.m.

Zoom Meeting Info here: https://www.unionps.org/272622_2?articleID=56771

post_text:
Union Football Team Builds In Offseason As New Stadium Is Built Beside Them

A quick history lesson: Union has won 8 state championships, the most recent in 2016.
With a new stadium being built the football team hopes that this season they will bring home a gold ball

While the pandemic is one distraction, Union High School Football has another one: a new stadium being built right beside summer drills.

This construction, however, has not slowed the team down, in fact, it‚Äôs been added motivation.

Coach Kirk Fridrich's team is glad to be out on the field.

"They are so used to having spring football. We are so used to doing some 7-on-7 this time and having all that stuff taken away from you, they can't wait to get back on the field,‚Äù said Fridrich. Continue: https://www.newson6.com/story/5f126805b076d21aa1512049/union-football-team-builds-in-offseason-as-new-stadium-is-built-beside-them

May 29 at 12:09 PM ¬∑

EDP Virtual Summer Camp

Looking for summer activities that seem like play, but keep academics alive? Look no further!

See https://www.unionps.org/edp for EDP Virtual Summer Camp lesson plans. Each week has a fun theme that is extended to include reading, math, science, cooking, art and physical movement.

post_text:
Union Reach 2020 will conduct a series of informative sessions in the month of July on the topics of race, inequity and education.

Starting Thursday, July 9, at 1 pm, a student-led listening session on ‚ÄúThe Color Achievement‚Äù will be facilitated by 2020-2021 students to discuss the impact of implicit bias and racial disparities on the academic achievement of students of color.

On Friday, July 10,at 2 pm, Oklahoma House Representative and Director of Network Growth for StriveTogether, Munroe Nichols, will discuss how certain disciplinary policies disproportionately target male students of color and the negative ripple effects these measures have on their future success in the session ‚ÄúSchool to Success Pipeline: Racial Equity for Black and Brown Male Students.‚Äù

Link for Zoom: https://bit.ly/38iyMxf

TULSA-HEALTH.ORG
Prepare to be Patriotic | Tulsa Health Department

Tulsa Health Department
July 1 at 9:50 AM ¬∑

The Tulsa Health Department will be closed on Friday in observance of Independence Day. The COVID-19 phone bank and testing appointments will be closed as well. Epidemiological investigations, including case notification and contact tracing, will continue to rapidly respond to confirmed cases of COVID-19 in our community.

Independence Day during a global pandemic is also a time for enhanced health and safety precautions. Keep these public health precautions in mind as you plan your 4th of July celebration safely.

post_text:
Public schools' reopening plans in Tulsa metro this school year: COVID-19 remains big concern

With a continued spike in COVID-19 cases across Oklahoma, many public school leaders are considering whether or not it is safe to reopen this fall.

One of the biggest challenges districts across the state will face is ensuring that students social distance.

While the situation remains fluid amid the pandemic, many districts have come up with tentative plans for the new semester.

Union Public Schools

Working behind the scenes to determine protocols and safety measures

Making plans to step up distance learning in case students would need to be learning from home

Surveying parents to determine willingness to send kids back to school and whether they are comfortable putting them on buses

Continue: https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/public-schools-reopening-plans-in-tulsa-metro-this-school-year

June 23 at 7:53 PM ¬∑

Do you have a 4 or 5 year old that needs to get enrolled into Union Schools? Or know someone that has a child that needs to get enrolled into PreK or Kindergarten? Roy Clark School staff will be coming to an apartment complex near you this Thursday! Come join the fun and be a Clark Cowboy this year!!

When: Thursday June 25, 2020

Where: Windsong Apartments at 12:00
Heatherstone Apartments at 2:00
Sugar Plum Apartments at 3:00

All Union enrollments are online at this time and we are coming to you! The Clark staff will have everything you need to get your child enrolled. There will be iPads, WiFi and laptops at each of the apartment times. Please bring all needed paperwork to get your child enrolled! We will be there with information and smiles to help!! Pass the word!!

June 24 at 10:31 AM ¬∑

The City of Tulsa will be going live at noon today for a press conference with Mayor G.T. Bynum, Dr. Dart, and Commissioner Keith.

Get notified when we go live:

1. Follow City of Tulsa Gov

2. While on the City of Tulsa Gov Facebook page, click "Following". Click the arrow next to Following and turn your notifications on.

post_text:
Union Reach Presents: Race, Identity, and Educational Systems June 26.

On Friday, June 26, 2020, at 2:00 pm, the Union Reach 2020 team will present a speaker panel on ‚ÄúRace, Identity, and Educational Systems.‚Äù This event will focus on how bias and racism within educational institutions can negatively impact the academic trajectory of students of color and their eventual success in secondary and postsecondary environments. Concepts such as intersectionality, identity, and abolitionist teaching will be discussed. Guest speakers include Dr. Dewayne Dickens, Director of Culturally Responsive Practices at TCC, Nate Todd, Dean of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at TCC, and Ramona Curtis, Director of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at TCC.

Info on Zoom: https://www.unionps.org/272623_2?articleID=56036

Concepts such as intersectionality, identity, and abolitionist teaching will be discussed. post_text:
Union Athletics Director Emily Barkley Named Oklahoma Interscholastic Athletic Administrators Association President for 2020-2021

Barkley brings 16 years of athletic administration experience to the position

‚ÄúI am excited to serve our professional organization in this capacity for the 2020-2021 school year. I am blessed to have been a part of the OIAAA board for the last 10 years. The relationships I have built with my colleagues as well as the platform we have to help athletic directors grow in our state is what I have enjoyed most,‚Äù Barkley said. ‚ÄúI look forward to working with our sport-specific advisory groups as well as the OSSAA to continue to make educated decisions in the best interest of our student-athletes, coaches and school communities. I realize we are in unprecedented times but I am optimistic about the challenges ahead.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.unionps.org/272623_2?articleID=55545

post_text:
A panel of the United Fresh Produce Association‚Äôs Produce Excellence in Foodservice award winners share COVID-19 challenges, adaptations at United Fresh Live

Mike Yip, district chef for Union Public Schools in Tulsa, OK, said when schools started offering take-home meals for pick-up, they collaborated with the food bank to expand offerings adults.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt want to leave out the adults, so the Community Food Bank of Eastern Oklahoma hired out restaurants to make adult meals and we would distribute those at a site.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt our peak we did over 15,000 meals a day, within a 2-hour delivery window,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a lot of meals.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.producebluebook.com/2020/06/16/chefs-share-covid-19-challenges-adaptations-at-united-fresh-live/#

shared_text:
Union 8th Grade Center
June 11 at 4:24 PM ¬∑

Attention parents of incoming 8th graders:

Here are a few resources to help your students prepare for their 8th grade math class and to prevent the ‚Äúsummer slide‚Äù. In addition, we are providing a document that is a blueprint for the second chance test for students to get into algebra: https://go.aws/2UxRefW . This should help guide their studies over the summer.

Information on the second chance test as well as the Orleans-Hanna test for Princeton students will be made available later this month.

Resources:

https://www.mathsisfun.com/‚Äì Free website with ads for students to access topics. Instruction and practice are provided

https://www.khanacademy.org/ ‚Äì Free website that students can access individually. Instruction and practice are provided.

https://nrich.maths.org/ ‚Äì Free website with problem-solving activities.

https://nrich.maths.org/ - Free website for students that can be searched by topic. Provides instruction for solving various types of problems.

shared_text:
Tulsa City-County Library
June 3 at 4:00 PM ¬∑

Join us next Thursday, June 11, on YouTube for this special virtual event commemorating Oklahoma's historic all-black towns.

Prior to the presentation, viewers are encouraged to watch Kari Barber‚Äôs documentary Struggle and Hope, available online at www.amdoc.org/watch/media/1127, and use the following questions as a study guide:
1.) By 1905, how many acres of land in Oklahoma were owned by black Americans?
2.) Shirley and Donnie Nero developed a museum to honor Oklahoma‚Äôs African American educators. In what all-black town is the Oklahoma African American Educators Hall of Fame located?
3.) In what year did the Tulsa Race Massacre occur?
4.) Established in 1850, what is the name of the oldest historically all-black town that still exists in Oklahoma?
4.) The town of Tullahassee‚Äôs zip code was changed from 74454 to what?
5.) In what year was the town of Clearview established?
The answers to these questions will be announced during the event.

Learn more here: https://www.facebook.com/events/948676455602374/?active_tab=discussion

post_text: Congratulations Nelienise Marmolejo!!! She is our fifth and final winner of the HSA ULatinx Challenge.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA
June 2 at 10:12 AM ¬∑

Congratulations Nelienise Marmolejo!!! She is our fifth and final winner of the HSA ULatinx Challenge. Nelienise describes more about her background and talent in her own words: "My name is Nelienise Marmolejo. I was born in Elkhart Indiana but was raised in Tulsa Oklahoma. My mom is Puerto Rican and my father is Mexican. For me, my talent represents a way to express what I feel and a way to escape from reality. Drawing makes me feel relieved, it‚Äôs a way for me to decompress. Through my art I communicate one of my life passions. I believe that everybody has a passion which they should express to make this world a better place."

The Oklahoma Educational Television Authority (OETA) will launch OETA Art Club, a new summer arts program designed to engage students in the arts as traditional summer programs cancel.

post_text:
Union Public Schools is closed for Memorial Day and there will be no meal service Monday. Monday meals were served last week.

Meal service will resume Tuesday.

Throughout the summer, curbside hours will be 9:30 a.m. ‚Äì 11:30 a.m. Mondays through Thursdays. Double meals will be served on Thursdays (for Friday.) Pick-up will be at:

Ellen Ochoa Elementary, 12000 E. 31st Street

6th/7th Grade Center, 10100 E. 61st Street

Jefferson Elementary, 8418 S. 107th E. Ave. Jeffer

Meals, which include breakfast and lunch ‚Äì and supper through June 30 ‚Äì will be available for FREE drive-through pick up for any children through the summer until further notice. Children do not have to be currently enrolled at Union Public Schools.

post_text:
Congratulations! Valeria Rodriguez!

She is our fourth winner for the #ulatinxchallenge.
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA
May 21 at 11:16 AM ¬∑

Congratulations! Valeria Rodriguez!

She is our fourth winner for the #ulatinxchallenge.

Here is more information about Valeria in her own words: "Hi my name is Valeria Rodriguez, I was born in Atlanta, GA, but my parents are from Aguascalientes, Mexico. Dance has always been a part of my life since I knew how to walk. The first classes I began taking were classic ballet and jazz. After a few years, I learned hip hop, and four years ago I joined Ballet Folklorico Sol Azteca at Saint Thomas Church to learn Ballet Folklorico. Ballet Folklorico (folkloric dance) is the traditional Mexican dances, that focuses on different states and regions of Mexico, with different music, vestuario (costumes), skirt movements, postures, choreography, feet, and body movements. Ballet Folklorico is where not only I love to dance but I get to represent my most beautiful culture through the Hispanic community, and I‚Äôm proud of that. The video I submitted represents the state of Jalisco with the song of La Madrugada (the dawn) and I‚Äôve created my own set of steps and movements. Hope you like it! "
text:
Congratulations! Valeria Rodriguez!

She is our fourth winner for the #ulatinxchallenge.

Union High School PTSA
May 21 at 11:16 AM ¬∑

Congratulations! Valeria Rodriguez!

She is our fourth winner for the #ulatinxchallenge.

Here is more information about Valeria in her own words: "Hi my name is Valeria Rodriguez, I was born in Atlanta, GA, but my parents are from Aguascalientes, Mexico. Dance has always been a part of my life since I knew how to walk. The first classes I began taking were classic ballet and jazz. After a few years, I learned hip hop, and four years ago I joined Ballet Folklorico Sol Azteca at Saint Thomas Church to learn Ballet Folklorico. Ballet Folklorico (folkloric dance) is the traditional Mexican dances, that focuses on different states and regions of Mexico, with different music, vestuario (costumes), skirt movements, postures, choreography, feet, and body movements. Ballet Folklorico is where not only I love to dance but I get to represent my most beautiful culture through the Hispanic community, and I‚Äôm proud of that. The video I submitted represents the state of Jalisco with the song of La Madrugada (the dawn) and I‚Äôve created my own set of steps and movements. Hope you like it! "

post_text: Amid school closures and distance learning, what can states, districts and schools do to support student growth? Webinar today at noon.
shared_text:
ZOOM.US
Welcome! You are invited to join a webinar: Conversations with State Chiefs: Supporting Student Growth Amid School Closures. After registering, you will receive a confirmation email about joining the webinar.

Oklahoma State Department of Education
May 20 at 11:06 AM ¬∑

Amid school closures and distance learning, what can states, districts and schools do to support student growth?

Join Superintendent Joy Hofmeister of Oklahoma, Superintendent Clayton Burch of West Virginia, Secretary Pedro Rivera of Pennsylvania, Commissioner Margie Vandeven of Missouri, and Dr. Javaid Siddiqi, President & CEO of The Hunt Institute as they discuss this topic and more tomorrow, May 21, at noon CST.

Register here: https://bit.ly/2YZ8kGv

post_text:
From academic rivals to inseparable best friends: Union High School seniors delighted to be named Academic All-State together

Two seniors at Union High School started out as bitter rivals desperate to reach the top of their class and leave the other behind. Now they‚Äôre best friends who are more than happy to share the limelight.

There‚Äôs nothing surprising about Keegan Knouse and Anna Claire McMullen making the short list of top public school seniors in Oklahoma. The two were named National Merit finalists this year ‚Äî a common denominator among Academic All-Staters.

But what may be surprising, at least to those who know them best, is the sheer joy they have for each other.

See story in Tulsa World: https://www.tulsaworld.com/news/local/education/from-academic-rivals-to-inseparable-best-friends-union-high-school-seniors-delighted-to-be-named/article_0f11b0cb-c913-525d-874a-c6d09996bc14.html

May 8 at 11:29 AM ¬∑

These are just some of the dedicated teachers, who have taught, hugged, laughed with, cared for and made an impression on your children in the past year alone. We miss you and look forward to a time when we can see other in the school. Have a safe and happy summer.

Special Message from Superintendent Dr. Kirt Hartzler:

During Teacher Appreciation Week, I want to take a moment to tell you how incredibly proud I am of you and your ability to change course quickly to deliver instruction in a whole new way. I would never have envisioned closing our buildings down unexpectedly and then recreating classroom instruction into a completely virtual platform in such a short period of time. I know‚Ä¶

Congratulations to these Union 8th Graders who have been accepted into the Early College High School program, offered through Union Public Schools and Tulsa Community College.

Three teams of people spent much of the day Friday, May 1, 2020, driving all over the Union Public Schools district in Tulsa/Broken Arrow to surprise the newest cohort of Early College High School. These students will start their journey next fall towards graduating from Union High School with their high school diploma and associates degree. Congrats to all these students and their families!

For more visit: https://www.unionps.org/236749_2?articleID=53124

#UnionSchools #TulsaCommunityCollege #EarlyCollegeHigh School #AllIn

post_text:
Oklahoma State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister said the State Board of Education is looking at plans for the fall semester.

Schools closed during the coronavirus pandemic in March and officially began distance learning in April.

Hofmeister said now they have time to prepare for the next semester and they're focusing on connectivity for students.

She said there's a good chance distance learning may be used at the beginning of the fall semester.
shared_text:
KTUL.COM
State superintendent discusses what fall semester may look like for Oklahoma schools
text:
Oklahoma State Superintendent Joy Hofmeister said the State Board of Education is looking at plans for the fall semester.

Schools closed during the coronavirus pandemic in March and officially began distance learning in April.

Hofmeister said now they have time to prepare for the next semester and they're focusing on connectivity for students.

She said there's a good chance distance learning may be used at the beginning of the fall semester.

KTUL.COM
State superintendent discusses what fall semester may look like for Oklahoma schools

post_text: Scholarship alert! We just received this year's scholarship application for IBC Bank's "We Do More" scholarship. We'll be giving two $1,000 scholarships to Union seniors!
shared_text:
Union College/Careers
May 5 at 12:11 PM ¬∑

Scholarship alert! We just received this year's scholarship application for IBC Bank's "We Do More" scholarship. We'll be giving two $1,000 scholarships to Union seniors!

The application is available in Canvas.

Deadline is May 15th. Email your application to your CCC advisor (Mrs. Ashley or Mrs. Gibson) ASAP!

Here are the qualifications:
1. A "Do More" attitude and demonstrated leadership in student and community affairs.
2. Student should have completed at least 50 Community Service hours within their Junior and Senior years.
3. Minimum GPA of 3.0 or above.
4. Student‚Äôs family income must meet qualified income: less than $50,000 adjusted gross income per year.
5. Top Ten students of the class are not eligible

post_text:
Union Public Schools District Chef Mike Yip is among nine of the country's most innovative chefs and foodservice professionals representing an array of culinary styles and backgrounds, who will be honored the week of June 15 during United Fresh LIVE!, as part of the United Fresh Produce Excellence in Foodservice Award Program. Yip is being honored for his service in K-12 foodservice.

The program honors chefs and their companies for their creativity in highlighting fresh produce on their menus, introducing diners to new flavors, and presenting creative ways to enjoy fresh produce. This year, the program also allows us a special way to praise their dedication to feeding their patrons. The coronavirus pandemic has devastated foodservice channels in unimaginable ways, and these chefs, among thousands across the country, have demonstrated fortitude and creativity as they have been forced to innovate their models to operate in this unprecedented environment.

Continue: https://bit.ly/3flaiXi

Three teams of people spent much of the day driving all over the district to surprise the newest cohort of Early College High School. post_text: Tulsa will end our shelter-in-place program and begin Phase One of our recovery at midnight on May 1.
shared_text:
Mayor GT Bynum
April 29 at 1:39 PM ¬∑

Tulsa will end our shelter-in-place program and begin Phase One of our recovery at midnight on May 1.

Over the last two months Tulsans have experienced two extremes: the absence of any social distancing practices, which would invite a public health disaster if left in place, and shelter-in-place, which has been effective in slowing the spread of the virus but is not sustainable over the long term.

Our local public health experts tell me we should expect COVID-19 to be with us for a while. The purpose of a phased reengagement moving forward is to identify the middle ground between the above extremes which we can use to go about our lives for the foreseeable future. Different industries have guidelines which will help them reduce risk for employees and patrons during this time.

The City of Tulsa will work with the Tulsa Health Department to enforce state and federal guidelines moving forward. You can view those guidelines, the new executive order, and answers to frequently asked questions here: https://www.cityoftulsa.org/covid-19

The Federal Statistics in Schools (SIS) website has a new page dedicated to at-home and distance learning. The page provides a variety of resources and materials ‚Äî videos, fun facts, warm-up activities and more ‚Äî for various grade levels that are easy to use at home. SIS resources help students bring census data to life and learn more about their community, state and country. These materials will help parents and caregivers ensure that their children are engaged, learning and having fun during this time.

Follow this link: https://www.census.gov/content/census/en/programs-surveys/sis/activities/distance-learning.html

Help is available from the Tulsa Area United Way, in partnership with Family and Children‚Äôs Services, Parent Child Center and Child Abuse Network.
shared_text:
Tulsa Area United Way
April 27 at 10:19 AM ¬∑

Tulsa Area United Way joins forces with Family & Children's Services, Child Abuse Network, Inc. and The Parent Child Center of Tulsa in a new coalition to provide education about ways to identify and report child abuse that could increase during our period of social distancing and virtual schooling. Preventing Child Abuse Webinar, scheduled from noon to 1 p.m. Wednesday, April 29, will provide more information about the "Look Out Reach Out campaign," and attendees can speak with our area experts.

To register: tauw.org/preventchildabuse. #LiveUnited #BetterTogether #covid19 #preventchildabuse

post_text:
It's a bummer missing school but look at some good things

By Rocco Salce, 10, Andersen Elementary

I am bummed about not going back to school, but I am excited about some things that I'm going to say in this letter.

One thing that I'm excited about is that we are on our own schedule. Because when I was at school I had to do work on the time I was assigned, but I can do it whenever now.

It's 11 a.m., and I'm still in my pajamas.

Continue: https://www.tulsaworld.com/opinion/letters/letter-to-the-editor-its-a-bummer-missing-school-but-look-at-some-good-things/article_90ced6f1-d2b8-55ac-9f27-f16aed9e39ab.html

His mom, Carrie Salce, said on Facebook, "Rocco‚Äôs letter to the editor was published in Sunday's Tulsa World. He did this all on his own. It‚Äôs 1:30 p.m. and he‚Äôs still in his pajamas. (Don‚Äôt judge) He‚Äôs pretty proud of himself and is requesting a treat for being important now. üôÑ"

Today we recognize Dr. Mark Calder, the father of sophomore player Jackson Calder. Dr. Calder fights on the front lines of the pandemic day in and day out like so many other medical professionals do. We can‚Äôt thank you enough for what you do for us & our entire community every single day.

Thank you Dr. Calder, truly.

UHS Choir auditions will be held virtually this year. Choirs offered to 10th-12th grade students are as follows: Union Jazz Choir (Mixed), Union Harmony (Treble), Union Advanced Mixed Chorus (Mixed), and Union Glee Chorus (Treble). Union Glee Chorus does not require an audition, however we encourage all students to audition! Audition forms must be submitted by Friday, May 8. We Miss U!

As we navigate this difficult time, we want to honor all of our fellow hardworking employees, parents and students for showing your spirit. Together We Make a Difference - even if we are temporarily apart.

It has been suggested we flood Facebook with pictures of us throwing the "U" on Friday, April 17, to show our support. Let's show the world how PROUD we are of this team, its students and parents!

#BringtheU #allin #UnionSchools #WeMissYou #RedskinsforLife

post_text:
Word to the wise:

In an act of social media solidarity with high school seniors who are finishing out their final semester at home, Facebook users are sharing their own senior photos with the hashtag #ClassOf2020.

It's a sweet sentiment, sure, but beware: Your post could help potential hackers crack into your private accounts, according to the Better Business Bureau, a nonprofit that tracks, among other things, internet scams.

https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/15/tech/facebook-senior-photo-scam-trnd/index.html
shared_text:
CNN.COM
Beware of the #ClassOf2020 photo trend. Scammers could use it to steal your information

A local printing company is trying to help mask the coronavirus, literally.

Inkwell Printing is making masks to help prevent the spread of COVID-19, but the masks are going fast.

Inkwell can also customize the masks for businesses, and they even made some masks for Union Public Schools with the school‚Äôs ‚ÄúU‚Äù logo.

See Tulsa World story: https://www.tulsaworld.com/communities/sandsprings/masking-the-coronavirus-inkwell-offers-signature-masks-to-stop-the-spread-of-covid-19/article_9fe9c2a4-ba01-5769-934c-3c440c64874e.html

post_text:
Letter to the Editor: Union staff pulled together distance learning in days

By Union Board President Ken Kinnear, Tulsa Apr 12, 2020

I would like to thank the hardworking teachers, administrators and staff of Union Public Schools for the terrific job they have done in the wake of COVID-19.

In spite of many obstacles, they have embraced the challenge.

Thankfully, our leadership had great foresight. With the passage of a significant bond issue in 2018, we purchased enough laptops that every student in grades 9-12 has a device to take home, as well as portable wireless devices.

See full letter: https://www.tulsaworld.com/opinion/letters/letter-to-the-editor-union-staff-pulled-together-distance-learning-in-days/article_67ed91bc-a0fe-5120-b7e0-e758cc6621c9.html

Students do not need a Union device in order to complete their Distance Learning assignments, but if you do not have a device at home, please come by Union High School tomorrow. In order to help minimize traffic issues, the entrance to the parking lot will NOT open until 2:15 p.m. If your child is in grades 6-8, please make sure to bring their student ID. Tulsa city and county officials banded together Tuesday to urge residents to wear cloth face coverings while performing essential tasks in public.

The guidance coincides with Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommendations, and officials emphasized that wearing a face covering doesn't necessarily protect the one who wears it, but it protects others in case someone is unknowingly infected, serving to limit the spread of COVID-19.

Do you have questions about what you CAN and CAN'T do under Tulsa's Safer at Home order? We have a "Yes/No" guide to help you navigate this difficult and unprecedented event. We know it's hard to put so many daily activities, habits and comforts on hold, but staying at home and only going out for the "Yes" necessities will help keep you and others safe. We'll get through this together, Tulsa. Even if we're six feet or more apart while doing it. Learn more at www.cityoftulsa.org/yesorno

post_text:
The class of 2020 matters and the High School hopes to celebrate that achievement in some form. A cap and gown drive-through only pick-up will be April 21 and April 22, from noon to 4 p.m. on the north side of the Union Collegiate Academy. These will be the only planned pick-up opportunities to receive your cap and gown and any remaining announcements orders.
A student ID of some type will be required. If you owe a balance, pay at Jostens.com or call 800-567-837. Cash and money orders will be accepted (no checks or credit cards.)
We understand the unprecedented challenge and sacrifice that has been thrown your way but we are working to make sure this will be a year to remember.

post_text:
Message from Mayor G.T. Bynum:

From 12 cases in Tulsa yesterday to 27 today. We should expect these confirmed cases to continue to rise in Tulsa over the next week as testing capacity increases. The labs that serve our local hospitals have increased their capacity to test patients, and the state is establishing increased testing through our state universities.

The day-by-day increases we will see are more a reflection of this increased capacity than an indicator of the rate at which the virus is spreading. These are not people that suddenly contracted COVID-19 - most of them already had it, but didn‚Äôt have testing available to confirm it.

I am told the best way to get in the queue for a test remains contacting your health care provider. If you don‚Äôt have one, you can contact 2-1-1 to be connected with a non-profit resource.

Even with increasing capacity, those prioritized first are those hospitalized or under observation by a doctor.

post_text:
Gov. Stitt announces a "Safer-At-Home" Order for Vulnerable Populations Until April 30

Oklahoma's Governor Kevin Stitt, along with members of the Governor's Solution Task Force, announced a "safer-at-home" order today during a press conference in Oklahoma City.

Gov. Stitt issued a "safer-at-home" order for the vulnerable populations until April 30.

Effective at midnight tonight, a restriction of any gatherings of 10 or more will take place across the whole state, says Gov. Stitt.

All nonessential businesses must close at 11:59 p.m. tonight and remain close for 21 days, Gov. Stitt says. He encouraged restaurants to stay open for delivery and/or curbside pick-up.

https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/gov-stitt-announces-a-safer-at-home-order-for-vulnerable-populations-until-april-30

Dear EDP parents,

Union EDP will be applying credits to accounts with payments for the school closing time period. If you requested a refund for spring break camp, we will issue those refunds once school business operations resume.

Full refunds will be processed for the second half of March as well as for any future payments that have been made for this school year. These refunds will also be processed once our business operations resume.

-Extended Day Program

post_text: GROCERY GIVEAWAY: Food On The Move is partnering with Tulsa Dream Center and giving out boxes of groceries to those in the community to help out with food during this unprecedented time on Friday. See post below
shared_text:
Tess Maune
March 19 at 3:05 PM ¬∑

GROCERY GIVEAWAY: Food On The Move is partnering with Tulsa Dream Center and giving out boxes of groceries to those in the community to help out with food during this unprecedented time on Friday. The boxes are free and filled with non-perishable items, drinks and even fresh meat. It‚Äôs a drive-thru giveaway... no one will have to get out of their car, volunteers will bring everything to you. Those who need a little extra help right now can go to the Tulsa Dream Center (200 W. 46th St. N.) Friday morning starting at 9:00. Volunteers will giveaway the groceries until noon, or whenever they run out (whichever comes first).

KOTV - News On 6

Oklahoma State Election Board Secretary Paul Ziriax on Wednesday declared an election emergency for local elections being held in 74 counties on April 7.

The election emergency declaration will require county election boards to accept resolutions adopted by the governing bodies of school districts, municipalities, technology districts and counties to move their April 7 elections to another date.

post_text:
Special Olympics Oklahoma Cancels All April & May Events Including Summer Games

Due to concerns related to the spread of the coronavirus, we are deeply saddened to announce that Special Olympics Oklahoma has made the very difficult decision to cancel all April and May sports training, competition and special events, along with our 2020 Summer Games scheduled for May 13-15. CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) has recommended that over an 8 week period from March 15, 2020, organizers hosting an in-person event of 50 individuals or more throughout the United States should cancel or postpone. Special Olympics, Inc. has recommended all Accredited Programs cancel events through the end of May, 2020.

https://t.e2ma.net/webview/m5y93d/3982a8cea9ceebff04d5937c65c1b93c?fbclid=IwAR2P2_pcJwFe6Pu2QCmIeGEgZni54qTmf8cSh3K6qX4ov0t0A4u3U-rtZSc

Save the date! The new Community Health Connection Clinic at Ellen Ochoa Elementary, 12020 E. 31st, will open to the public this spring. A ribbon cutting ceremony is planned for 3:30 p.m. Thursday, April 30.
This project is a partnership Community Health Connection (CHC), Union Public Schools (UPS) and the City of Tulsa. The clinic is under construction on the Ellen Ochoa Community School campus with funding from the City of Tulsa‚Äôs Vision 2025 bond funds.
The new 25,000 sq. ft. building will replace CHC‚Äôs existing east side clinic that is located on East 21st St. The new clinic will provide medical services and a pharmacy. It will also provide dental services, which the existing 21st Street clinic could not do.

Congratulations to Ellen Ochoa fourth grade teacher Lisa Shotts, who has been named a Newsmaker Award winner by the Tulsa Chapter of the Association for Women in Communications. ‚ÄúThis is such a distinguished honor and I am still in shock I was chosen and in awe of the other honorees,‚Äù Shotts said. Shotts was honored for her work as executive director for Gaining Ground and being named the Union Public Schools Teacher of the Year in 2019.

post_text: The Union Adult Learning Center (UALC) is holding its last enrollment period for the 2019-2020 school year for adults wishing to complete their high school equivalency.
shared_text:
Gitzel Puente is at KJRH.
March 9 at 7:15 AM ¬∑ Tulsa, OK ¬∑

Good morning! The story I covered today is extra special for me because my mom earned her GED many years ago when we moved to the U.S. Finishing high school is a no-brainer for many of us, but sometimes there are challenges that get in the way. But it's never too late to continue your education! Take a look at this story :)

For more information on how you can enroll for GED or HiSet classes, visit Union Adult Learning Center and read our story on our website: https://www.kjrh.com/news/local-news/last-ged-hiset-enrollment-for-2019-2020-begins-this-week-at-union-adult-learning-center

Thank you Union Public Schools - Tulsa, OK for setting the interviews up with Dr. Hartzler and Amy!

post_text: Detective Jason Weis, of the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office, talked to Jefferson fourth and fifth graders about the safe use of social media this morning.
shared_text:
Jefferson Elementary School
March 6 at 1:53 PM ¬∑

Detective Jason Weis, of the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office, talked to Jefferson fourth and fifth graders about the safe use of social media this morning. He cautioned students against sharing pictures, especially inappropriate ones. In fact, he said, students under 13 should not be on social media, and warned them about online predators.

Since joining TCSO in January of this year, Det. Weis has taught nearly 5,000 Tulsa County children how to protect themselves against online predators, according to the office.
