Tulsa actor Wesam Keesh has been cast in an NBC drama pilot, "Echo," as a series regular in this high-concept crime procedural.

"A team of investigators who solve the highest-profile crimes by sending heroes into the past in the body of the victim. They assume the victim's identity and must race against time to prevent the crime before it happens," according to a synopsis on imdb.com.

Keesh, who attended Union High School and the University of Tulsa, tweeted: "So blessed and appreciative to announce I‚Äôm joining another @nbc project! Thank you to my family, friends, fans, colleagues, and reps for your support over the years~ So stoked!"

https://www.tulsaworld.com/entertainment/tulsa-actor-wesam-keesh-cast-in-nbc-crime-procedural-pilot/article_58e80031-a2d2-5b80-bc9b-6cf83e7a9941.html

post_text:
Union Students in Tulsa Tech‚Äôs Fashion Class are Changing the Lives of Young Women Worldwide

A thread, a stitch and a passion to help others in need. Students in Tulsa Tech‚Äôs Foundations of Fashion and Apparel Design class at Union High School are learning more than just clothes. They are working to change the lives of people they probably will never meet, by teaming up with the non-profit Days for Girls.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something that shouldn‚Äôt be a big deal, but helping with this project can have a huge impact on young women in Africa,‚Äù Kareem Ahmed, a student in the class said. ‚ÄúNow they can go to school or work, and that can have a major impact on their lives.‚Äù
As part of the class, the students join the Family, Career and Community Leaders of America (FCCLA), a CareerTech student organization. Helping make a difference is just one-way FCCLA pushes its students.

Continue: https://gtrnews.com/union-students-in-tulsa-techs-fashion-class-are-changing-the-lives-of-young-women-worldwide/

A thread, a stitch and a passion to help others in need. Students in Tulsa Tech‚Äôs Foundations of Fashion and Apparel Design class at Union High School are learning more than just clothes. They are working to change the lives of people they probably will never meet, by teaming up with the non-profit Days for Girls.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something that shouldn‚Äôt be a big deal, but helping with this project can have a huge impact on young women in Africa,‚Äù Kareem Ahmed, a student in the class said. ‚ÄúNow they can go to school or work, and that can have a major impact on their lives.‚Äù
As part of the class, the students join the Family, Career and Community Leaders of America (FCCLA), a CareerTech student organization. Helping make a difference is just one-way FCCLA pushes its students.

Continue: https://gtrnews.com/union-students-in-tulsa-techs-fashion-class-are-changing-the-lives-of-young-women-worldwide/

GTRNEWS.COM
Union Students in Tulsa Tech‚Äôs Fashion Class are Changing the Lives of Young Women Worldwide

post_text: Grove is #PoweredbyFlightNight
shared_text:
Robert B Grove Elementary PTA
February 28 at 12:07 PM ¬∑

Grove Elementary students enjoyed a trip to space today with a visit from Astronaut Col. Paul Scott Lockhart and the Flight Night presentation, sponsored by the Space Foundation, NORDAM and Tulsa Regional STEM Alliance. The school hosted two assemblies this morning.
While Lockhart took students on a ‚Äújourney‚Äù to the space station using props and video, other volunteers were in classroom, engaging students in math and engineering activities, such as measuring how far little cars travel down ramps. Sand paper was even used for part of the activities to serve as ‚Äúgravity.‚Äù
Educators said it was fun to see kids excited to engage in space activities. #PoweredbyFlightNight
The trip was part of the annual Flight Night Space Week, which included visits by Lockhart around the area.

post_text: Spring Pep Assembly 2020
shared_text:
Union High School PTSA added 169 new photos to the album: Spring Pep Assembly 2020 ‚Äî at Union Public Schools - Tulsa, OK.
February 26 at 5:10 PM ¬∑ Tulsa, OK ¬∑

High School hosted a pep assembly for its spring sports, recognizing student athletes for their achievements and giving them a great send-off into the spring.
Varsity Pom, who is celebrating its 2nd place national finish in Florida over the weekend, received loud cheers. The achievement was even more table because the highest Pom ever received previously was 3rd place.
Special Olympics team mates also received loud applause. These student-athletes will compete in May during the annual State Special Olympics. Be sure to participate in the Polar Bear Trot on march 7, which is a fundraiser for the team. Register here before March 3: https://www.unionps.org/236749_2?articleID=47080
The assembly, which had an Hawaiian theme, featured Cheer and Highsteppers, Band, Choir, and more teas, as well as games and activities sprinkled throughout the event.

post_text:
Once again, Union Public Schools was recognized as the number one fund raiser among education institutions at the annual Tulsa Area United Way recognition luncheon.

Union was the top fund-raiser, followed by Broken Arrow Schools and Tulsa Public Schools. Union's Chief Communications Officer Chris Payne, who oversaw Union's campaign, represented the district at today's luncheon.

Altogether, TAUW raised $26,028,910 during last fall‚Äôs campaign drive.

In the photos here, you will see a slideshow image in the background, featuring Union Service Center receptionist Diane Word, who did her part ‚Äì simply by wearing a hat with money she received from donors who passed by her during the campaign.

post_text:
Teacher of the Year Spotlight: Brittany Hamilton

Third grade teacher Brittany Hamilton was named the 2019-2020 Teacher of the Year for Rosa Parks Elementary School. She has been with Union since 2016.

Hamilton said, ‚ÄúI became a teacher because of the wonderful examples set by my mom and by my grandpa. They both taught me that being a teacher is to be a life-long learner with an unconditional love for every student.‚Äù

Hamilton said, ‚ÄúMy favorite subject to teach is writing because it challenges my students and me to become stronger readers, writers, thinkers, and problem-solvers. Writing is an ill-defined problem with endless solutions, so students are able to show their creativity in their work.‚Äù

Continue: http://bit.ly/2SqzIcx

Union Public Schools will recognize its 2019-2020 School Site Teachers of the Year ‚Äì and name the District Teacher of the Year ‚Äì at a formal reception at 4:45 p.m. February 26, at the Union Performing Arts Center, 6636 S. Mingo Road.

post_text:
It was just two days ago that Darnaby students were showing off their skills at STEM Expo 2020 at the new Union Innovation Lab, and they were doing it again today.
Darnaby Elementary School hosted a Project Lead the Way/STEM Showcase tour for area educators, including Broken Arrow Public Schools, who wanted to learn how Darnaby, and by extension Union Public Schools, has become a national model in the field.
Among those in attendance was Assistant Superintendent Sandi Calvin.
Principal Chris Reynolds and teacher Suzanne Martin talked about the program and the positive impacts their focus on collaborative, team-building skills and emphasis on the curriculum has had on students. Martin said she is a firm believer their students, now in middle school, have been so successful in robotics is because of their early participation in the PLTW curriculum since kindergarten.
But the real stars of the show were, of course, the students.
Fresh off their presentations at the STEM Expo, the students had their presentations polished and ready.
text:
It was just two days ago that Darnaby students were showing off their skills at STEM Expo 2020 at the new Union Innovation Lab, and they were doing it again today.
Darnaby Elementary School hosted a Project Lead the Way/STEM Showcase tour for area educators, including Broken Arrow Public Schools, who wanted to learn how Darnaby, and by extension Union Public Schools, has become a national model in the field.
Among those in attendance was Assistant Superintendent Sandi Calvin.
Principal Chris Reynolds and teacher Suzanne Martin talked about the program and the positive impacts their focus on collaborative, team-building skills and emphasis on the curriculum has had on students. Martin said she is a firm believer their students, now in middle school, have been so successful in robotics is because of their early participation in the PLTW curriculum since kindergarten.
But the real stars of the show were, of course, the students.
Fresh off their presentations at the STEM Expo, the students had their presentations polished and ready.

post_text:
Union High School‚Äôs esports club shows off gaming skills

See Fox 23 video: http://bit.ly/2So1XIX

Students in the Union High School Esports Club showed off their skills this week in the 2020 STEM Expo.
Coach Benjamin Jackson said the club started this year and already has 50 members that meet every day for about two hours.
He said the students compete against leagues across the state every other week.
The club helps teach the teens how to keep a schedule, handle stress, develop critical thinking skills and problem-solving abilities, Jackson said.

post_text:
Teacher of the Year Spotlight: Lacy Dake

Fourth grade teacher Lacey Dake has been named the 2019-2020 Teacher of the Year for Jarman Elementary School.

Dake started teaching at Union Public Schools in 2010 at what used to be the Union Intermediate High School.

Furthermore, she said, ‚ÄúI am a Union Lifer! I went to Grove Elementary and graduated in 2006. I graduated from Missouri State University in 2010 with my bachelor‚Äôs of science in elementary education. I am also certified in early childhood Education.

Dake said, ‚ÄúI became a teacher to make a difference in children‚Äôs lives ‚Äì to know they have someone in their corner rooting them on through life. I love working with kids. I hope to inspire them and spark a love for learning just as my past educators did for me.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.unionps.org/236749_2?articleID=46984

Union Public Schools will recognize its 2019-2020 School Site Teachers of the Year ‚Äì and name the District Teacher of the Year ‚Äì at a formal reception at 4:45 p.m. February 26, at the Union Performing Arts Center, 6636 S. Mingo Road.

Teacher of the Year: Jeri Potter

Reading specialist Jeri Potter has been named the 2019-2020 Teacher of the Year for Grove Elementary School.

‚ÄúI have always known I wanted to be a teacher,‚Äù Potter said. ‚ÄúIt was my dream to set up a class, establish a routine and teach little minds. I loved my years as a classroom teacher. The relationships built with students and families were so meaningful and lasting.‚Äù

She started with Union Public Schools in 2013, and all six at Grove Elementary as a reading specialist.

Continue: http://bit.ly/2GZUkC7

Union Public Schools will recognize its 2019-2020 School Site Teachers of the Year ‚Äì and name the District Teacher of the Year ‚Äì at a formal reception at 4:45 p.m. February 26, at the Union Performing Arts Center, 6636 S. Mingo Road.

post_text:
Voter registration deadline is Friday for Oklahoma's primary

Friday is the deadline to register to vote or update existing registrations for the March 3 Oklahoma presidential primary.

Registration forms are available at elections.ok.gov and at local election boards, post offices, tag agencies and libraries. Updates, such as changes in party or address, can be made online through the OK Voter Portal on the election board website.

‚ÄúEven if you‚Äôre already registered to vote, it‚Äôs important to make sure your registration is up-to-date and that you know where your polling place is. You can find your polling place, change your party affiliation, make limited address changes and request an absentee ballot all in one location using our OK Voter Portal,‚Äù said Oklahoma Election Board Secretary Paul Ziriax.

Continue: http://bit.ly/2UuHaFe

Union Public Schools are using disinfectant spray packs to battle against germs during flu season.

To keep their students healthy and their buildings clean, Union schools are using packs full of disinfectant to get rid of the flu, mold or any other germs a school might be dealing with.

‚ÄúA principal would call and say hey we have 20 kids out today with flu. Can we get the packs over there?‚Äù said Joshua Robinson with the district. ‚ÄúSo, we‚Äôll send that over and spray the building.‚Äù

The Roy Cark Elementary Glow Dance will be 6 to 7:30 p.m., Friday February 7.
We will deck the gym out in black lights and glow in the dark fun. A professional DJ will be there to help make the dance extra amazing. Admission is $2 for students and $1 for adults. Family packs are available for pre-purchase. Included in the Family Pack is 1 pizza, 4 sodas, 4 cookies, 4 glow items and admission for 4 people all for $20! Concessions are also available for purchase ala carte.

When voters in Tulsa and Broken Arrow passed a five-year bond for Union Public Schools in February 2018, they allowed the district to provide long-term planning and implementation of some pretty big ideas, including providing a digital device for every Union student. During the 2019-2020 school year, Union rolled out laptops to every student in grades 9-12. Thank you, patrons, for #BelievinginU.

#UnionSchools #BondDollarsatWork

Learn more: https://www.unionps.org/BondProgress2020

post_text:
High school basketball: Union girls knock off No. 1 Booker T. Washington

Union girls basketball coach Joe Redmond said he wanted his best shooters on the floor and his daughter, Mae, was definitely one of those.

The senior guard went 4-for-5 from 3-point range and scored a team-high 14 points as her No. 6 Redskins upended No. 1 Booker T. Washington 70-53 in a key Frontier Conference game Tuesday at the UMAC.

Union led almost from start to finish and Redmond‚Äôs outside shooting helped the Redskins overcome the Hornets‚Äô strategy of clogging the middle and trying to take away Union‚Äôs powerful inside game.

https://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/high-school/high-school-basketball-union-girls-knock-off-no-booker-t/article_9bab0f0b-1ca4-582f-9bfb-28616a3a4b48.html

We are requesting in-kind donations, monetary donations, or items from our Amazon Wish List! You can donate online or find the link to our Amazon list at https://csctulsa.org/baby-shower/

Thank you so much for your support! This event will make a difference in the lives of many new families across East Tulsa.

Join us at the Polar Bear Trot Saturday, March 7!

Raise Money for our Union Special Olympians with a super fun 5k and fun run/walk at the Union Freshman Academy Track Field!

Build Community, support special Olympians, have a great time. Food, fun and festivities. ALL ABILITIES WELCOME!

Special Olympics is the highlight of the year for our athletes! We want them to have the best experience possible, so come support and join in the fun!

5k and Fun Run - $20 for adult , $15 for students

1 mile Fun Run - $10 per person , free for children 5 years and under and Team Union Special Olympic Athletes

5k registrants who sign up before March 3, 2020 will receive a Polar Bear Trot Beanie!

If you register morning of the event, it will be $25 per adult and $20 per student. Fun Run will remain the same @ $10 per person

Register Online:
https://runsignup.com/Race/OK/BrokenArrow/PolarBearTro

post_text:
Christa McAuliffe would have been NASA‚Äôs first designated teacher in space. She and six crewmates were killed when the Challenger space shuttle broke apart shortly after takeoff on Jan. 28, 1986 - 34 years ago today.

Christa McAuliffe Elementary was built in 1988 and named in honor of the teacher ‚Äì the first teacher in space - who died during the Challenger Space Shuttle disaster on Jan. 28, 1986.

U.S. Sen. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire on Tuesday commemorated the life of Christa McAuliffe, saying "34 years later, the loss of Christa McAuliffe and the crew of Space Shuttle Challenger continues to be felt across the country. Christa was a trailblazer who sought to educate and enlighten her students and those across the nation"
shared_text:
McAuliffe Elementary - A Community School
January 28 at 11:52 AM ¬∑

U.S. Sen. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire on Tuesday commemorated the life of Christa McAuliffe, a Concord High School teacher who died in the space shuttle Challenger disaster 34 years ago today.

McAuliffe would have been NASA‚Äôs first designated teacher in space. She and six crewmates were killed when the Challenger broke apart shortly after takeoff on Jan. 28, 1986.

‚ÄúFor Granite Staters, and for teachers and educators across the United States, there will always be a special place in our hearts for Christa McAuliffe,‚Äù Shaheen, D-N.H., said Tuesday on the 34th anniversary of the disaster. ‚ÄúChrista McAuliffe was on a mission to space, but as a teacher, she was also on a personal mission to educate and enlighten. Today, we remember and honor her bravery, her passion for teaching and her tremendous legacy.‚Äù

https://boston.cbslocal.com/2020/01/28/challenger-disaster-anniversary-christa-mcauliffe/

‚ÄòHonor Her Bravery‚Äô: NH Senator Remembers Christa McAuliffe On Challenger Explosion Anniversary
The Concord High School teacher died in the disaster 34 years ago.

The Concord High School teacher died in the disaster 34 years ago.

See more at
boston.cbslocal.com

post_text: Thank you to Channel 2, Scripps Local Media and the Scripps Howard Foundation from McAuliffe Elementary School and Union Public Schools.
shared_text:
McAuliffe Elementary - A Community School
January 23 at 4:25 PM ¬∑

Thank you to Channel 2, Scripps Local Media and the Scripps Howard Foundation from McAuliffe Elementary School and Union Public Schools.

---- Photos from today.

McAuliffe Elementary received a surprise gift from Channel 2 KJRH and its parent company, Scripps Local Media ‚Äì a $10,000 grant which includes a new wrap for its mobile reading van and two new books for each student.

Channel 2 Anchor Karen Larsen and representatives for Scripps Local Media made the announcement shortly after 11 a.m. on live television today as part of National Reading Day and the 2 Cares for the Community Partnership and Give a Child a Book campaign.

The announcement also happened to be part of McAuliffe‚Äôs Winterfest today. The students will be able to pick up their books during the community event which runs from 5 to 6 p.m.
Channel 2 also ran additional news segments of McAuliffe‚Äôs reading events throughout the day.

The assistant secretary of the U.S. Department of Education, Frank Brogan, who leads the country‚Äôs Office of Elementary and Secondary Education, will tour Darnaby Elementary Schools between 12:30 ad 2 p.m. today to learn more about its STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) offerings and programs.

Assistant Secretary of Education Frank Brogan will be in Tulsa to take a tour several schools.

‚ÄúThe Department regularly sends senior leaders to visit high performing and innovative schools all across the country,‚Äù Darnaby Principal Chris Reynolds said. ‚ÄúThe Department has been aware of the robust gains academic growth made by our students over the past year and would like to learn more about it. The Department is particularly interested in learning more about the STEM-related activities the school incorporates, the school‚Äôs Lego league, as well as the school‚Äôs participation in Character Counts!‚Äù

Continue: http://bit.ly/2NRe7aP

ImpactTulsa will release its 6th annual Community Impact Report on January 23 from 6 to 8pm at OSU-Tulsa. The report features public education data analysis for the Tulsa region that spotlights progress and defines opportunity gaps that exist while making a powerful call to action for all stakeholders in Tulsa County. This year‚Äôs theme is Pathways to Opportunity which emphasizes the importance of cradle to career interventions and collaboration among adjacent sectors in support of public education.

https://www.impacttulsa.org/communityimpactreport/

post_text:
The Board of Education on first reading considered one proposed option for the 2020-2021 school calendar at its meeting Monday night. The proposed calendar has the first day of school starting on Thursday, August 13, which is about a week earlier than has been typical for the district. However, the upside is that it would enable families to take off the entire week of Thanksgiving, and if approved, provide greater balance between the first and second semesters. January 4, 2021, would be the start date for the spring semester. The last day of school ‚Äì if no snow days were used ‚Äì would be May 18. In the event all snow days are used, May 31 would be the last day. The Board will consider approval of the calendar during second reading at its next meeting on February 10.

Comments about the proposal may be directed to board@unionps.org.

post_text:
The Union High School Wind Ensemble will perform at 7:30 p.m. tonight at the Tulsa Performing Arts Center, Chapman Hall, as part of the 2020 Oklahoma Music Educators Association Annual Winter In-Service Conference.

Union Bands Director Charles Pisarra will serve as conductor and Amy Mayes will serve as associate conductor. They will be assisted by several Union faculty members.

See program: https://s3.amazonaws.com/scschoolfiles/1967/wind_ensemble_2020.pdf

The ensemble will perform four pieces: ‚ÄúFirefly,‚Äù ‚ÄúFour Scottish Dance,‚Äù ‚ÄúSymphony No. 2 (2017)‚Äù and ‚ÄúFamishus Fantasticus.‚Äù

For ticket information, visit: https://www.tulsapac.com/events/2020/okmea-all-state-festival

post_text:
Reminder: There will be no school Monday, January 20, in observance of Martin Luther King, Jr., Day.

The annual MLK Day Jr. parade will be at 11 a.m. that day.

The Parade will begin at Detroit and John Hope Franklin Blvd, proceed east on John Hope Franklin Blvd to Greenwood, South through the Greenwood Business District to Archer, then west on Archer to Elgin. The parade will be televised on KTUL ‚Äì News Channel 8 beginning at 11 a.m. The 2020 MLK Parade winners will be announced during the parade. For related information, visit https://www.mlktulsa.com/

post_text:
Union to host 6th Grade Meetings for Incoming Students

Union 7th Grade Principal Clayton Hucke will begin making rounds around the district to meet with fifth grade students during the school day and talk about their transition to the 6th Grade Center next year. Parents also are invited to similar meetings in the evenings at all of the elementary school sites.

Hucke plans to visit each of the elementary school sites, starting at Boevers Elementary School Tuesday, January 14. He will serve as the 6th Grade Class Principal and stay with this cohort of students for the next two years.

post_text:
Early Childhood Center closing early due to power outage; parents requested to pick up their child

Rosa Parks Early Childhood Education Center is currently without electricity. Under CAP guidelines, school closes if the building is without electricity for more than two hours. This guideline applies ONLY to the Early Childhood Center. We request that parents pick up their child as soon as possible. All after school events have been cancelled. Extended day will take place as scheduled for those already enrolled in EDP. Also, phones are down at the school, so you will be unable to get through. We appreciate your patience. ‚Äì Message from Chief Communications Officer Chris Payne

One of the ways you can support SHAKA week is by purchasing SHAKA attire! Please click on the link below for our t-shirt store. The deadline to order a shirt or sweatshirt is Thursday January 16. Shirts will be delivered to the your selected site. All proceeds will benefit St. Jude‚Äôs Children‚Äôs Hospital.

https://unionshaka2020.itemorder.com/sale

Additional information on how you can support and contribute to SHAKA week (January 27th-January 31st) will be sent at a later date.

Meghan Bender
Director of Student Life

post_text:
The idea that a school district can own a student‚Äôs data‚Äîfrom semester transcripts and grades to awards and recognitions, even diplomas‚Äîis one that‚Äôs garnered increased acceptance in recent years. But a school system is merely a steward of that information‚Äîstudents are the masters.

This is Todd Borland‚Äôs philosophy. As the executive director of technology for Oklahoma‚Äôs Union Public Schools, Borland is putting that theory into practice, leading a first-of-its kind blockchain technology initiative to put data back where it belongs: into the hands of students.

https://www.togglemag.com/case-studies/todd-borland-union-public-schools/

post_text: Schedule Change! Beginning Monday, January 6, school at the 6th/7th Grade Center will start five minutes later than the fall 2019 schedule.
shared_text:
Union 6th7th Grade Center
January 2 at 11:14 AM ¬∑

Beginning Monday, January 6, school at the 6th/7th Grade Center will start five minutes later than the current schedule. The tardy bell for 7th Grade will be 9:05 a.m. Monday through Thursday and 9:30 a.m. on Friday. The tardy bell for 6th Grade will be 9:35 a.m. Monday through Thursday and 10:00 a.m. on Friday. The end times will not be impacted and we will maintain this schedule for the remainder of the school year. We apologize for any inconvenience this might cause you. If you have any questions please direct them to Charlie Bushyhead, Associate Superintendent at bushyhead.charlie@unionps.org.

post_text: In what has become an annual tradition at McAuliffe, staff teams dressed up as characters from Christmas movies for a contest during the last collaboration of the year.
shared_text:
McAuliffe Elementary - A Community School
December 20, 2019 at 12:30 PM ¬∑

In what has become an annual tradition at McAuliffe, staff teams dressed up as characters from Christmas movies for a contest during the last collaboration of the year. Points were given for participation, accuracy and costume. The fifth grade team won for their commitment to acting and taking a fall - dressed as the main characters from Home Alone. Mr. Martin can take a fall!

4th Grade came in 2nd with Whoville and the specials team came in 3rd with the Nutcracker. Other scenes represented included The !2 Days of Christmas, "Santa Buddy," The Polar Express, Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, A Charlie Brown Christmas and Elf on a Shelf!

Video to come!

post_text:
On Saturday, December 14, Asbury Methodist Church hosted a holiday party at Grove Elementary. We had 670 students and parents attend this event. There were carnival games, snacks, prizes and a puppet show. Students won bikes, scooters, & remote control cars. Each child was able to receive a pair of gloves and a hat. Everyone had so much fun! We are so thankful for the Asbury Elves who brought so much holiday cheer to our school.‚Äù

Kayla M. West
Grove Elementary
Community Schools Coordinator

post_text:
Dub Maddox joins Union as offensive coordinator

Dub Maddox is departing Victory Christian after two seasons as head football coach to become Union‚Äôs offensive coordinator.

Maddox, while he was a Jenks assistant, faced Union and Redskins head coach Kirk Fridrich in six state championship games.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an amazing opportunity, this wasn‚Äôt something I was looking for,‚Äù Maddox said Monday. ‚ÄúCoach Fred reached out after the season to talk about offensive football and we talked hours about strategies and past games, and after that asked if I would consider coming to Union. We used to be 53 yards apart (on opposite sidelines) and now we‚Äôre sitting at the same table.‚Äù

Continue: https://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/high-school/high-schools-victory-head-coach-dub-maddox-joins-union-as/article_9dc2461f-4ee3-5b2e-9b79-3ce715af1c09.html

post_text: Google representatives visited the UFA and Mr. Webb's Multimedia and Image Management class to teach an hour of coding.
shared_text:
UHS Freshman Academy
December 10, 2019 at 11:19 AM ¬∑

Yesterday, Google representatives visited the UFA and Mr. Webb's Multimedia and Image Management class to teach an hour of coding. They are kicking off their CS Ed Week (Computer Science Education Week) this week starting 12/9-12/15.

The Union Freshman Academy was one of 10 locations in the Northeast Oklahoma area to talk about coding and how Computer Science can lead to a great career. Ed Corona was the lead for this team coming out today, along with David Hansen and Joel Kallin, all Data Center Operations employees at the Pryor Google Data Center.

The class worked on a coding program called Grasshopper. This exercise took the students through a list of codes to modify a game, ‚ÄúGrasshopper.‚Äù After they completed the course, students received certificates & asked questions about Google, like ‚ÄúWhat classes can I take in high school to work towards a career at Google?‚Äù and one comment ‚ÄúThank you for keeping YouTube running.‚Äù
text:
Google representatives visited the UFA and Mr. Webb's Multimedia and Image Management class to teach an hour of coding.

The Union Freshman Academy was one of 10 locations in the Northeast Oklahoma area to talk about coding and how Computer Science can lead to a great career. Ed Corona was the lead for this team coming out today, along with David Hansen and Joel Kallin, all Data Center Operations employees at the Pryor Google Data Center.

Community School is both a place and a network of supportive partnerships between the school and the community.

Union‚Äôs Community Schools approach to education seeks to equalize the playing field for all students through a comprehensive, four-pronged approach, providing layered supports for children and families: Expanded Learning Time, Collaborative Learning Practices, Family and Engagement Practices, and Integrated Student Services

post_text: Congratulations to UFS members Joey Terrell and Haley Aziere for placing first and second respectively at the MLK, Jr. Oratorical Contest! First prize is $500, second prize is $350, and both will perform the "I Have a Dream" speech in January. Kaiden Ivey, sophomore, UHS, was third-place winner of the MLK Oratorical Contest and wins $250. She and Joseph (the 1st place winner) are both Early College HS students. He and Haley (the 2nd Place winner) will both be performing the ‚ÄúI Have a Dream‚Äù speech at a dinner in honor of Dr. King on Jan. 18.

post_text:
Join us in celebrating the life of Coach Trimble!

All are welcome to attend on Wednesday, December 4 at 6:30 p.m. at the Mabee Center on the campus of Oral Roberts University (81st & Lewis - enter through North Lobby doors).

In lieu of flowers, those who wish to honor Coach Trimble's legacy or show support to his girls may donate to any of the following:

Allan Trimble Family Support Fund: A Care Account has been established for the Trimble Family at Arvest Bank. Stop by any location to make a donation.

Trimble Strong Foundation: www.trimblestrong.org/donations

Golden Years: The Life and Legacy of Coach Allan Trimble, Join the community and show support by helping publish a coffee table book on the Legacy of Coach Trimble and Jenks Football. www.allantrimblelegacy.com

We are so proud of our former Renegade Regiment Drum Major, Cecily Yoakam, who is now the Advocacy and Educational Resources Coordinator for Bands of America. She was interviewed by Dan Potter after one of our Grand National Championships performances last week. Cecily is certainly a testament to the life-changing impact of fine arts involvement.

post_text: Union High School students put their mechanical skills to the test today repairing bicycles that will be donated to needy children this Christmas season as part of the Bikes for Kids project. These students are part of the Career Connect program that provides students with opportunities to explore a variety of careers while still in high school. - Chief Communications Officer Chris Payne
